description.text:
Removable bolts (yes they are bolts not screws) for the "shiny new" and "industrial strength" Artemis printer. I used the "Nut Job" program and adjusted the parameters as needed. This is the third print on this printer and it is beyond expectations. The following are parameters for Mikes "nut job" scad file. An STL file has been provided.

/ [Bolt and Rod Options] /

//Head type - Hex, Socket Cap, Button Socket Cap or Countersunk Socket Cap (ignored for Rod)
head_type = "hex";//[hex,socket,button,countersunk]
//Drive type - Socket, Phillips, Slot (ignored for Hex head type and Rod)
drive_type = "socket";//[socket,phillips,slot]
//Distance between flats for the hex head or diameter for socket or button head (ignored for Rod)
head_diameter = 25;
//Height of the head (ignored for Rod)
head_height = 12;
//Diameter of drive type (ignored for Hex head and Rod)
drive_diameter = 5;
//Width of slot aperture for phillips or slot drive types
slot_width = 1;
//Depth of slot aperture for slot drive type
slot_depth = 4;
//Surface texture (socket head only)
texture = "exclude";//[include,exclude]
//Outer diameter of the thread
thread_outer_diameter = 6.75;
//Thread step or Pitch (2mm works well for most applications ref. ISO262: M3=0.5,M4=0.7,M5=0.8,M6=1,M8=1.25,M10=1.5)
thread_step = 1.8;
//Step shape degrees (45 degrees is optimised for most printers ref. ISO262: 30 degrees)
step_shape_degrees = 45;
//Length of the threaded section
thread_length = 7;
//Countersink in both ends
countersink = 2;
//Length of the non-threaded section
non_thread_length = 1.8;
//Diameter for the non-threaded section (-1: Same as inner diameter of the thread, 0: Same as outer diameter of the thread, value: The given value)
non_thread_diameter = 5.75;

description.text:
I designed this for my girlfriend to dry her herbs from the garden. I mounted a 12v 120mm fan to the top and used flat-head M5 screws and Ny-lok nuts on top.
Size:

  • 144mm - X-Axis
  • 172mm - Y-Axis
  • 162.4mm - Z-Axis

BOM:

  • Printed Parts; 1 shelf, 4 drawers, 4 dividers
  • 1- 120mm fan (12v is best, but 5v will work)
  • 4- 25mm M5 flat head screws
  • 4- M5 Ny-lok nuts

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Shelf should be rotated so that back is on build plate, approximately 400 grams of material needed, 144x172x162.4 layout and roughly 1 day printing.

Drawers and Dividers can be printed 1 each in a 184x180.8x42.4 layout, with the divider laying flat to the side of the drawer. This print requires approx. 140 grams of material and 8 hours to print.

Total print time : Approx. 56 hours
Total material : Approx. 960 grams

In the past, I've had some devices which required C batteries, mostly LED lights. I'd use a large dowel rod and a screw, but with 3d printing no need to get the dowel...

Using these devices for auxiliary lighting could continue to use quite a few batteries. My lamp, for example, requires 3 C batteries, at 1.5 volts each equals 4.5 volts, or close enough to use a USB 5v power supply. Even with multiple batteries, many of these devices wire the batteries in series, so you only need to make two connections, one to the positive, and one to the negative side.

To attach the wire (to both sides, I'm using an M3 12mm screw with a nut
To replace one battery print one body and two caps (one for each end). The bottom of the body I added a removable circle to assist with bonding to the build plate.

I'd recommend printing in high-quality mode, I didn't need supports or rafts. 20% infill worked fine for me.

Please note, I don't have the wires connected to the USB power supply in these pictures, it's not useful until you wire it up.

title: 'Bingo Airsoft Designs' Tokyo Marui MP7 AEP top dead centre mod

description.text:
The TM MP7 with a Bingo Airsoft Designs (BAD) kit in it runs rings around every other airsoft MP7 ever made, we all know that. However at an original ~230fps, the standard hopup chamber was never designed to hop much over a 0.25g BB. What happens is the arm is only getting pulled down by the adjuster on one side, and that both limits the hop power you can apply to the BB, and also makes it hook a little. In my case I also found that it wouldn't hold the extreme hop setting well, backing off after a mag or so.

This mod sorts that out completely. You can set your hop and forget it, it'll hop a 0.3g BB to the moon with no trouble at all, and the hop arm is pushed down in the middle so no more hooking.

You'll need:

  • An 8x8 M5 gutter bolt nut to slide into the groove
  • An M5 bolt to do the pushing (file the end nice and flat). A mushroom head is the best as they have the smallest OD, and use the smallest size allen key of the M5 bolt range.
  • A optional spring to apply tension so it never adjusts itself. You can use an M4 mag catch spring cut to an appropriate length

I drilled a 5mm hole through the rail behind the faux screw to allow access with an allen key, but you could just set it and forget it.

The ring on the end slips over the front of the Jack unit in the BAD kit, and these ensures perfect alignment always.

The pictured prototype doesn't have the retaining groove on the right hand side as per the model. That keeps the too fairly snugly together. I did design it to be a snug fit at the front helped with a little super glue, but in practice it's fine to leave it as is, which leaves this mod fully reversible.

title: "The Stinger" Tiny Whoop Low Profile Mount

description.text:
"The Stinger" is a low profile camera/vTX combo mount for Tiny Whoop pilots who demand an unobstructed view. In addition, this mount substantially reduces the height of the aircraft which is beneficial when whizzing through obstacles at high speeds.

Features include:
A stiff and durable 15 degree camera mount. A small rubber band secures the camera.

description.text:
Fits the 1-3/4" diameter roll cage of a Polaris RZR 900.
Printed in PLA at standard settings. Supports are needed as the clamp is printed on its side to avoid stress in the layers when clamped around the roll bar of the RZR.
Works with Go-Pro and Go-Pro clones, and their accessories.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.18 mm

Infill:

50% Hexagonal

Notes:

Works well printed in either PLA or ABS.

Requirements

Requires a 1/4"-20 X 1-1/4" long hex bolt and nut, a #8-32 X 1" long machine screw, and a 5 mm - .8 X 50 mm long hex bolt and nut. All of these can usually be found at your local Home Improvement Store.
The hinge portion of the clamp needs tapped #8-32 at the smaller hole. This can be accomplished just by forcing the machine screw through the hole, but it's cleaner with a tap.
The longer knob holds a 5 mm hex head bolt. These have a smaller hex than normal SAE bolts and still must be driven into the knob.
The small knob holds a 1/4"-20 hex head bolt.
Designed in Google Sketchup.

description.text:
I have printed a few things using TPU on the Cetus with mixed results. Much too frequently I'd have failed prints because the TPU would bend and push sideways, out from between the feeder gear and the cold-end of the nozzle. My solution was to re-design the guide for the filament feeder so the gaps above and below the gear and guide are much, much smaller.

Printed on the Cetus itself with Cetus' own PLA*. Works well so far. I'd probably recommend printing in ABS.

  • UPDATE: Printed it in Hatchbox Black ABS, and it's working wonderfully. I was having an issue with the PLA version bending a little bit. Not enough to cause any issues with prints, but it probably would have deformed more if I had kept using it. The ABS version is looking much better.

I'm thrilled to unveil my new 3D printed AM radio! I was inspired by the diy crystal and foxhole radios of the early 1900's, but I created my own design to be as simple as possible. I made a few animations to help assist in explaining how this mystifying device can work with so few parts.

These should be easy to find online. The springs I got are sold at Joann Fabrics. Search Silver Cord End Springs but any similar 5mm diameter springs should work.

description.text:
Replacement rubber foot for a standard KitchenAid mixer. I printed this in Polymaker Polyflex and noticed it had some shrinkage issues - so the foot is sized for a tight fit to account for this shrinkage. If printing with Ninjaflex or other materials, you may need to print out and adjust the scale if it doesn't fit properly. The polyflex material is a lot more rigid compared to the stock rubber foot, so Ninjaflex would probably be better suited for this.

The foot design was simplified since the stock part (pictured on the left) is designed for injection molding - the 3D printed version doesn't not require the optimized features and material removal.

title: TBS Crossfire Immortal Antenna Mount for Armattan Rooster

description.text:
UPDATED 02/21/2018:
"TBS Crossfire Immortal Antenna Mount for Armattan Rooster V2"
I've changed the dimensions of some of the holes and I've made some modifications to the shape of the part, not only with the intention of getting a more robust and durable holder but also to get a better adjustment of the antenna

Knowing that horizontal antenna location is not the optimal due to its polarization, I still decided to give it a try so, this is my version of a mount for a "TBS Crossfire Immortal Rx Antenna" made specifically for Armattan Rooster.

Only 2 g added in weight!

Super easy change, just print a couple and throw them in your toolbox with a couple of zip ties, if the original breaks, the change takes no more than two minutes!

Please (please, please, please, please, please, please, please) share if you make it!
(AT LEAST PLEASE LET ME KNOW IF THE DESIGN WORKS FOR YOU!)

Can be printed in any material, PLA, ABS or even soft materials as TPU (However the soft ones are not my favorite since I prefer some "rigidity" to avoid contact with props when the holder is under stress (like in a crash!) and to hold better the bolts...well, for this you can add some small thin washers too ...)

Cheers!

description.text:
Created this ventilation system for the winter time. I print pretty often and my printer is in the garage which is below mine and my wife's room. Usually use PLA and PETG, so there isnt much smell, but I know it must release some kind of harmful particles into the air... Not sure if this helps any. Don't have a way to test, but it helps me sleep at night..

Costs about $25 for the two USB fans off Amazon and the pipes I used to run it to a nearby window.

Link to the fans used (2 fans for $13.98 Prime): http://a.co/dW2OO7o

Attach approx 1-1/4 in hose to vent system.

This is a simple laser cut, 3 layer square that has an inner measurement of 2" marked out.

Check the SVG in Inkscape for the layers. I choose 5mm for the two outer pieces and 3mm for the straight edge. Two 5/8" Dowels go through the layers to align them properly and keep everything square. I used wood glue to laminate the pieces with the dowels in place. I sanded them manually on a flat surface to make sure they were completely flat. I covered them in some paint since the surfaces weren't pretty. The straight edge has a coat of tung oil on it so that the markings are easy to read.

Enjoy.

Just the thing for when your figures have something that they want to display, be that a diploma from Miskatonic University, an ancient dagger full of arcane energy, or just some rare butterflies.

The width and height are parametric, as well as the gap between the front panel and the backing plate. You can also change the size of the nameplate.

For the full effect, you'll need to cut a piece of clear plastic to the width/height you've specified and glue it into the frame piece. Then glue whatever you want to the backing plate, and finally glue the backing plate into the frame.

If you like this sort of thing and want to see more, be sure to follow us on Twitter and/or join the discussion on our Facebook page. Also check out our Youtube channel

print_settings.Notes:: 6 layers top and bottom as well as 6 shells. I am using this formula because Maker's Muse suggested it compared to something like 100% infill and the typical 3 top and bottom and 3 shells.

description.text:
I am sharing this project currently to see if there is interest in me actually ironing out all the bugs that are invariably still present. If I get a bit of positive feedback I will be sure to carry on with this as a shared model.
If it is functional, as I hope it will be, I would suggest it over the earlier spoolholder I have shared only because in my experience the vertical holder causes the filament to be ground up by the stock extruder's metal body at the entrance. I believe an offset location will help mitigate this.
All that said, I haven't even printed this yet myself. The hole spacing "looks" good. Looks aren't everything. :) I plan to print sections to help me find fitment issues that aren't readily apparent.
I have included basically two different versions. The spoolholder and melziholder are the full models to date with everything hopefully where it needs to be. The mainbody, bodytail, holderleft, and holderright are broken up to hopefully fit the X1s bed area. Once all the sections are printed, the body and tails can be superglued together as well as the halves of the melziholder.

title: Huawei Nexus 6p & Watch 2 Bed Side Dock

description.text:
First design print; A charging dock station for the Huawei Nexus 6p and watch 2. Designed to sit on the wooden bed rest on the bed head. It was created by placing both my watch and phone would rest on the bed beside me as I slept and this way its a bit more organised.

The modular two-part design is mostly used in the event if the main part that holds the phone and the watch is printed incorrectly or to the wrong dimenions so I would not have to print the whole design out again. All photos of the end result and the CAD design are shown as well as the STL files if anyone is looking to print the same thing.

Printer:

Tevo Tornado

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Material: PLA 1.75mm

Filling is Required

Due to the Gcode having two print jobs the nozzle was required to move between each causing the plastic tail to drag while printing. The excess is not too bad to file down being very thin and easy to sand down. I would recommend using a coarse sandpaper to remove the large excess then use a finer sandpaper resolution to smooth the surface.

Increase Watch Base Tolerance

The Charger for the huawei watch 2 was an extremely tight fit, therefore it would be better to increase the diameter of the cut-extrude of 0.25mm to ensure a nicer fit.

Decrease Slide Face Tolerance

The sliding mechanism part of the design is too free to move as I accounted for a 0.5mm tolerance all around, I would decreased this tolerance by 0.25mm as well for a more snug physical slide.

author: LeoAnthony

description.text: rehausseur ventilateur 40x40x30

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this with black Push plastics ABS, PLA would probably work fine here. You will want support for some of the motor housing sections.

description.text:
I have occasional need to inspect long underground drainage culverts. Robots to do this task are hideously expensive, so I decided to make my own. This robot is designed to use off the shelf components such as RC truck axles and gearboxes, motors and other easily obtainable robotics bits, and will eventually have a blue robotics pressure hull up top.

This rover will be a tethered vehicle and will mainly go up and down dry or submerged tunnels in a straight line forward and backwards. It will eventually have an RC surface running mode. It could be adapted for wheel stearing easily if there becomes a need. As configured currently I expect it will be able to fit into 8" or 10" culverts.

This project is temporarily on hold pending a few things, but I will be returning to it. The next piece will be better seals for the motor arms, and then the front camera / light assembly and housing clamps for the pressure housing. the rear will have a tether attachment point for my existing ROV tether.

Parts lists, build components, better pictures, etc will be forthcoming. The RC parts are mainly Traxxis RC components and differential parts. At the slow speeds this will be utilizing, I don't anticipate the gearing will be a concern. The two rear motors have position encoders. I haven't decided on the robotics platform as of yet.

Parts that don't yet exist: The front and rear swaybar anchors (which fit in the area with the two brass heat set inserts for and aft), the pressure hull mounts, light brackets, the rear tether mount, Possibly mud fenders later. Version 3 of the motor arms will have an integral gasket.

print_settings.Notes:: I would recommend printing this in something with a high heatresistance... PETG would probably be fine if all you ever intend to print is PLA, but PETG tends to become soft as soon as it reaches 80C... the Keenovo heats up a lot further if you ask it... so for printing PETG i would recommend the clips to be in ABS or ASA... if you intend to print ASA or ABS with a 100C bed temperature I'm not sure these clips are suitable at all unless printed in Nylon or something else that's very strong also when heated up.
print_settings.Infill:: doesnt matter, just give it a couple of extra walls/perimiters

description.text:
Bed Clips for Cr10 5S with Keenovo 50x50 230V AC Silikon heatbed mounted on the aluminum plate.

Since the original clips shoot of the printer when Keenovo heatbed warms up and I've seen shots of bigger clips also comming of during prints I made a quick and dirty solution that screws into the profiles under the bed.

I used spare tslot nuts from my CR10 S5 along with some M5 & M4 screws (you need a total of 4 tslot nuts and 4 screws M4 and/or M5)
the screws i used was 40mm and was a perfect fit.

! Please note: If you mounted a Bltouch-sensor the gcode-auto wipe feature could catch the bedclips.... the nozzle itself will pass without a problem, but the BLT-Touch might catch it... so place the front left clip clear of the wipe-zone or adjust the machine settings so it wipes deeper into the bed or closer to the center

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

doesnt matter, just give it a couple of extra walls/perimiters

PETG would probably be fine if all you ever intend to print is PLA, but PETG tends to become soft as soon as it reaches 80C... the Keenovo heats up a lot further if you ask it... so for printing PETG i would recommend the clips to be in ABS or ASA... if you intend to print ASA or ABS with a 100C bed temperature I'm not sure these clips are suitable at all unless printed in Nylon or something else that's very strong also when heated up.

title: Modular Lightsaber #4 - Build your saber
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Join the Dark Side with this modular lightsaber !

I wanted to get a lightsaber, really cheap for cosplays or decoration. I wanted something, easy to make, with no electronic circuit which has to be made each time you construct a saber.

I use a LED keyring torch as a lamp which is at the back of the saber. The light is not very powerful of course, but it could be enough if you are using it in dark places. Moreover, you can add a little piece of plastic to change the color oh the saber (like a Kyber crystal !)

The LED i'm using : Infapower F026 5-LED Keyring Torch

You can find what you need to build the lightsaber here : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2751428

I find it perfect for kids who want to get a customisable saber, or as a decoration for your house.

description.text:
This simple frame is ideal to fill empty walls with pictures and photos. It is designed to be used with plexiglass of size 18x13cm, for my purpose it had thickness 0.75mm but other size should fit too.
There are two holes for nail so frame can be placed vertical or horizontal.
To hold plexi and picture inside press clips and match them into holding holes.
Place frame on printing table as you look at it at wall, use support for smooth surface inside due to matching of plexi.
You need:
Frame x1
Frame clips x16
Plexiglass size 18x13mm
You can hang your picture without it too.
I hope you would like your arts at walls :).

The russian armored ship POTEMKIN actually started as a project about 12 years ago. Back then, there were no 3D printers and I started to make it form plastic resins. For some reasons I abandoned the project.

Two years ago I restarted the project. I think I have some good results. The hull is almost ready - I've printed several parts OK.

The scale is about 1:200 and is approx. 60 cm long, but I'm thinking of making it in 1:87 scale ( H0 gauge) which is my favourite, but needs much more details, as the model will be abot 1,4 meters long.

This is an attempt to convert a cheap 10" Chinese tablet into a 2-in-1.

The tablet, like many others, was supplied with a clip-on case with a folding cover which is supposed to double as a stand. Since it folds, it is pretty useless as a platform to hold a keyboard: it isn't much better as a stand and won't do what I wanted - hold the tablet on my knee when I'm in an armchair.

The kickback stand was designed on Openscad, so you can easily alter it to suit your needs and tastes. The stand needs to be glued to the back of the case but, as it is only around 6mm tall, that's not too much of a disadvantage. For this, you can use sticky pads or double-sided carpet tape, which are fairly easy to scrape off. The stand holds my tablet exactly as I wanted.

Other published stands I could find need to grip the tablet at the lower edge of the screen. This isn't possible with the case open to support a keyboard.

I chose the TechGear Active Strike USB Bluetooth Keyboard as it was quite cheap (£12), the right size and had what I needed. This comes with a foam base stuck on with 5 tabs of glue: I pulled that off. I attached he keyboard to the soft side of the tablet front cover with Velcro self-adhesive tape. Put the tape on with the soft (loop) bit facing the screen and the hard (hook) side on the back of the keyboard, and don't join them up until the tape has had a few hours for the adhesive to set. When the keyboard is attached, it holds the front cover rigid and is also easy to remove.

The combination works quite well as a 2-in-1 and I'm no longer tempted to buy one.

I'm still learning Openscad. If anyone can tell me what causes the warning message, I'd be grateful.
